properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, expected tonight and Friday. Rainfall amounts of 40 to 60 mm are expected. Locally higher amounts are possible in thunderstorms on Friday. Rain will taper off Friday evening. This rain is the result of a Colorado Low that will track through parts of northeastern Ontario on Friday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-23T01:28:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-22T09:29:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1272639577.2020
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, Temiskaming Shores - Temagami, Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for snow squalls to develop on the eastern shore of Reindeer Lake Thursday evening and persist through Friday. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate with local amounts of 15 cm possible. ### Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-23T02:19:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-22T10:20:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0987641873.2020
Area: Lynn Lake, Leaf Rapids, Pukatawagan
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: More early season snowfall expected on Friday as Arctic air arrives. Below seasonal temperatures to continue through the weekend. A low pressure system will pass just off Vancouver Island Friday morning and move onto the Washington coast late in the day. Meanwhile, modified Arctic air will advance southward through the B.C. interior. By Friday afternoon, the Arctic front is expected to reach Kamloops and pile up against the east side of the Rockies. With a somewhat cool airmass already in place, widespread snow is expected from the Chilcotin and 100 MIle area to the Fraser Canyon and eastward to the Kootenays. Snow may become mixed with rain over southern and eastern portions of this area. Currently, forecast snowfall amounts may range from about 5 to 15 cm. The system will move out of the province on Saturday but Arctic air will make its way through the rest of the southern interior. Temperatures of 10 degrees below seasonal normals are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-23T00:58:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-22T08:59:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2059540103.2020
Area: Whistler
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: More early season snowfall expected on Friday as Arctic air arrives. Below seasonal temperatures to continue through the weekend. A low pressure system will pass just off Vancouver Island Friday morning and move onto the Washington coast late in the day. Meanwhile, modified Arctic air will advance southward through the B.C. interior. By Friday afternoon, the Arctic front is expected to reach Kamloops and pile up against the east side of the Rockies. With a somewhat cool airmass already in place, widespread snow is expected from the Chilcotin and 100 MIle area to the Fraser Canyon and eastward to the Kootenays. Snow may become mixed with rain over southern and eastern portions of this area. Currently, forecast snowfall amounts may range from about 5 to 15 cm. The system will move out of the province on Saturday but Arctic air will make its way through the rest of the southern interior. Temperatures of 10 degrees below seasonal normals are expected. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Sasktel Planned Service Outage In Iroquois Lake, Echo Bay And Shell Lake
properties.Summary:
Description: On October 22nd, from 12:00 am (midnight) until approximately 6:00 am, SaskTel crews will be performing maintenance on the network infrastructure serving the Iroquois Lake and Echo Bay area. During that timeframe, SaskTel Internet, Wireless, and Landline Phone services will be unavailable. SaskTel Internet and Wireless services in the Village of Shell Lake will also be unavailable, however, Shell Lake customers will have access to Landline Phone services during the outage.
Expires: 2020-10-22T10:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK SaskTel, 2020-10-21T09:28:06-06:00, 998A048B-F4C5-6DF3-CBA4-D0FC7C40B627
Area: Iroquois Lake, Echo Bay and Shell Lake
properties.Author: SK SaskTel

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowfall with 10 to 20 cm of accumulation is expected today. Advancing cold air from the north will combine with an upper disturbance to produce snow primarily south of the Trans-Canada Highway. Some areas of the Cypress Hills, especially near north-facing slopes, will likely see snowfall of 10 to 20 cm by the time the snow tapers off tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-22T13:11:03-00:00

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lived snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are expected to continue tonight into Thursday along parts of the south coast of Great Slave Lake. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-22T19:22:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-22T03:23:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1902049767.2020
Area: Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. A cold airmass combined with northwest winds off the warm waters of Lake Winnipeg will create a favourable setup for snow squalls beginning Thursday afternoon. Snow amounts will be highly localized but may exceed 20 to 30 cm in some areas by the time the snow squalls diminish on Saturday as the wind shifts to a more northerly direction. This snow squall watch may be upgraded to a snow squall warning as the event nears and the areas impacted by the heaviest bands of snow become more clear. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-23T01:22:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-22T09:23:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1631407435.2020
Area: Poplar River, Berens River, Little Grand Rapids and Atikaki Prov. Park, Bloodvein
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry mix of precipitation expected this evening into Friday. A warm front through the area will bring the chance for snow, rain, and ice pellets. Rainfall totals of 30 to 50 mm are possible. Snowfall totals of 5 cm are also possible over areas more to the north, closer to Kirkland Lake and Foleyet. This is a result of a Colorado Low that will track through parts of northeastern Ontario on Friday. Rainfall warnings may be required as the event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-23T01:37:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-22T09:38:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1276573491.2020
